docs.lead_paragraph: LAST month, a small group of prominent American track and field athletes volunteered to submit to drug-control tests by a physician attached to the United States Olympic Committee's Task Force on Drug Control. The tests were conducted privately, as part of a series of new drug-control procedures adopted by the U.S.O.C. in the aftermath of drug-related controversies at last summer's Pan American Games. The results will remain confidential between the athletes and Dr. Harmon Brown, the physician. The athletes will be allowed to take other such non-punitive tests between now and next June's United States Olympic trials. ''It's an opportunity to educate athletes about drug testing and eliminate the fear factor,'' said Dr. Brown, the director of the student health center at California State University-Hayward and one of nine physicians from various parts of the country who were named to serve on the U.S.O.C. task force. ''There's so much misinformation about drugs and their effect. The attitude we're taking with athletes on this is that maybe you've been involved in past practices and taking something, here's an opportunity to be counseled and clean up your act before the trials.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Ann Crittenden, a former correspondent for The New York Times, is based in Washington. THE IMAGES FLICKERING ON THE television monitor are painfully hard to watch. In one, a mother reaches out her arms to her 6-month-old son across the room, and asks him to ''come to Mommy.'' The infant, too young to be mobile, stares at her intently. After a few more minutes of entreaty, she turns away, saying, ''O.K., if you don't love me, I don't love you.'' In another film, an animated little girl sings and dances around a room, while her depressed mother slumps over a table, ignoring her. Finally, the 3-year-old drops dejectedly to the floor. The mother turns, noticing the child for the first time. ''You're tired, too, huh?'' she asks.

docs.lead_paragraph: News Analysis Who decides when to let a baby who is born with severe physical defects die? That question has generally been left to the state courts. But when the Federal Government stepped into the Baby Jane Doe case on Long Island last week, it started a legal battle with ramifications that will be felt by doctors, hospitals and the parents of infants born with defects. No case involving a decision to withhold medical treatment from a handicapped infant has ever been considered by the United States Supreme Court.

headline.main: A LEGAL KNOT IN BABY CASE
